body:
> At least, when I try `warn`, it does not work for me with JUnit 5.13.0:

You're right: `warn` doesn't work, it must be `warning`.

> I would prefer JUnit to fail in case user configures an invalid value for `junit.platform.discovery.issue.severity.critical`.

This was implemented to be consistent with how other enum-based configuration parameters are evaluated (in the Jupiter engine):

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/1fc5958a092d1be11872f04e850ed9760dcf6953/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/config/EnumConfigurationParameterConverter.java#L63-L66

That being said, we should discuss if we generally want to change that behavior for 6.0.
Yeah, making JUnit fail on illegal property values might probably make sense.
**Team decision:** Fail for all enum-based configuration parameters with invalid values across Platform, Jupiter, and Vintage.

rename.to: Reject invalid enum values of configuration parameters

issue.title: Fail for invalid enum constants supplied as configuration parameters

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/api/org.junit.platform.commons/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
